the-gotpointercapture-event.name: gotpointercapture_event
the-gotpointercapture-event.summary: The gotpointercapture event is fired when an element captures a pointer using setPointerCapture().
the-gotpointercapture-event.title: Document: gotpointercapture event

the-gotpointercapture-event.name: ongotpointercapture
the-gotpointercapture-event.summary: The ongotpointercapture property of the GlobalEventHandlers mixin is an EventHandler that processes gotpointercapture events.
the-gotpointercapture-event.title: GlobalEventHandlers.ongotpointercapture

the-gotpointercapture-event.name: gotpointercapture_event
the-gotpointercapture-event.summary: The gotpointercapture event is fired when an element captures a pointer using setPointerCapture().
the-gotpointercapture-event.title: HTMLElement: gotpointercapture event

the-lostpointercapture-event.name: lostpointercapture_event
the-lostpointercapture-event.summary: The lostpointercapture event is fired when a captured pointer is released.
the-lostpointercapture-event.title: Document: lostpointercapture event

the-lostpointercapture-event.name: onlostpointercapture
the-lostpointercapture-event.summary: The onlostpointercapture property of the GlobalEventHandlers mixin is an EventHandler that processes lostpointercapture events.
the-lostpointercapture-event.title: GlobalEventHandlers.onlostpointercapture

the-lostpointercapture-event.name: lostpointercapture_event
the-lostpointercapture-event.summary: The lostpointercapture event is fired when a captured pointer is released.
the-lostpointercapture-event.title: HTMLElement: lostpointercapture event

the-pointercancel-event.name: pointercancel_event
the-pointercancel-event.summary: The pointercancel event is fired when the browser determines that there are unlikely to be any more pointer events, or if after the pointerdown event is fired, the pointer is then used to manipulate the viewport by panning, zooming, or scrolling.
the-pointercancel-event.title: Document: pointercancel event

the-pointercancel-event.name: pointercancel_event
the-pointercancel-event.summary: The pointercancel event is fired when the browser determines that there are unlikely to be any more pointer events, or if after the pointerdown event is fired, the pointer is then used to manipulate the viewport by panning, zooming, or scrolling.
the-pointercancel-event.title: HTMLElement: pointercancel event

the-pointerdown-event.name: pointerdown_event
the-pointerdown-event.summary: The pointerdown event is fired when a pointer becomes active. For mouse, it is fired when the device transitions from no buttons depressed to at least one button depressed. For touch, it is fired when physical contact is made with the digitizer. For pen, it is fired when the stylus makes physical contact with the digitizer.
the-pointerdown-event.title: Document: pointerdown event

the-pointerdown-event.name: pointerdown_event
the-pointerdown-event.summary: The pointerdown event is fired when a pointer becomes active. For mouse, it is fired when the device transitions from no buttons depressed to at least one button depressed. For touch, it is fired when physical contact is made with the digitizer. For pen, it is fired when the stylus makes physical contact with the digitizer.
the-pointerdown-event.title: HTMLElement: pointerdown event

the-pointerenter-event.name: pointerenter_event
the-pointerenter-event.summary: The pointerenter event fires when a pointing device is moved into the hit test boundaries of an element or one of its descendants, including as a result of a pointerdown event from a device that does not support hover (see pointerdown).
the-pointerenter-event.title: Document: pointerenter event

the-pointerenter-event.name: pointerenter_event
the-pointerenter-event.summary: The pointerenter event fires when a pointing device is moved into the hit test boundaries of an element or one of its descendants, including as a result of a pointerdown event from a device that does not support hover (see pointerdown).
the-pointerenter-event.title: HTMLElement: pointerenter event

the-pointerleave-event.name: pointerleave_event
the-pointerleave-event.summary: The pointerleave event is fired when a pointing device is moved out of the hit test boundaries of an element. For pen devices, this event is fired when the stylus leaves the hover range detectable by the digitizer.
the-pointerleave-event.title: Document: pointerleave event

the-pointerleave-event.name: pointerleave_event
the-pointerleave-event.summary: The pointerleave event is fired when a pointing device is moved out of the hit test boundaries of an element. For pen devices, this event is fired when the stylus leaves the hover range detectable by the digitizer.
the-pointerleave-event.title: HTMLElement: pointerleave event

the-pointermove-event.name: pointermove_event
the-pointermove-event.summary: The pointermove event is fired when a pointer changes coordinates, and the pointer has not been canceled by a browser touch-action.
the-pointermove-event.title: Document: pointermove event

the-pointermove-event.name: pointermove_event
the-pointermove-event.summary: The pointermove event is fired when a pointer changes coordinates, and the pointer has not been canceled by a browser touch-action.
the-pointermove-event.title: HTMLElement: pointermove event

the-pointerout-event.name: pointerout_event
the-pointerout-event.summary: The pointerout event is fired for several reasons including: pointing device is moved out of the hit test boundaries of an element; firing the pointerup event for a device that does not support hover (see pointerup); after firing the pointercancel event (see pointercancel); when a pen stylus leaves the hover range detectable by the digitizer.
the-pointerout-event.title: Document: pointerout event

the-pointerout-event.name: pointerout_event
the-pointerout-event.summary: The pointerout event is fired for several reasons including: pointing device is moved out of the hit test boundaries of an element; firing the pointerup event for a device that does not support hover (see pointerup); after firing the pointercancel event (see pointercancel); when a pen stylus leaves the hover range detectable by the digitizer.
the-pointerout-event.title: HTMLElement: pointerout event

the-pointerover-event.name: pointerover_event
the-pointerover-event.summary: The pointerover event is fired when a pointing device is moved into an element's hit test boundaries.
the-pointerover-event.title: Document: pointerover event

the-pointerover-event.name: pointerover_event
the-pointerover-event.summary: The pointerover event is fired when a pointing device is moved into an element's hit test boundaries.
the-pointerover-event.title: HTMLElement: pointerover event

the-pointerup-event.name: pointerup_event
the-pointerup-event.summary: The pointerup event is fired when a pointer is no longer active.
the-pointerup-event.title: Document: pointerup event

the-pointerup-event.name: pointerup_event
the-pointerup-event.summary: The pointerup event is fired when a pointer is no longer active.
the-pointerup-event.title: HTMLElement: pointerup event

dom-element-haspointercapture.name: hasPointerCapture
dom-element-haspointercapture.summary: The hasPointerCapture() method of the Element interface sets whether the element on which it is invoked has pointer capture for the pointer identified by the given pointer ID.
dom-element-haspointercapture.title: Element.hasPointerCapture()

dom-element-releasepointercapture.name: releasePointerCapture
dom-element-releasepointercapture.summary: The releasePointerCapture() method of the Element interface releases (stops) pointer capture that was previously set for a specific (PointerEvent) pointer.
dom-element-releasepointercapture.title: Element.releasePointerCapture()

dom-element-setpointercapture.name: setPointerCapture
dom-element-setpointercapture.summary: The setPointerCapture() method of the Element interface is used to designate a specific element as the capture target of future pointer events. Subsequent events for the pointer will be targeted at the capture element until capture is released (via Element.releasePointerCapture()).

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 82, setPointerCapture() throws InvalidPointerId for an invalid pointerId argument. From Firefox 82, it throws the specified NotFoundError exception. See bug 1662124.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 82, setPointerCapture() throws InvalidPointerId for an invalid pointerId argument. From Firefox 82, it throws the specified NotFoundError exception. See bug 1662124.

dom-element-setpointercapture.title: Element.setPointerCapture()

extensions-to-the-element-interface.name: Element
extensions-to-the-element-interface.summary: Element is the most general base class from which all element objects (i.e. objects that represent elements) in a Document inherit. It only has methods and properties common to all kinds of elements. More specific classes inherit from Element.
extensions-to-the-element-interface.title: Element

dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointercancel.name: onpointercancel
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointercancel.summary: The onpointercancel property of the GlobalEventHandlers mixin is an EventHandler that processes pointercancel events.
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointercancel.title: GlobalEventHandlers.onpointercancel

dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerdown.name: onpointerdown
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerdown.summary: The GlobalEventHandlers event handler onpointerdown is used to specify the event handler for the pointerdown event, which is fired when the pointing device is initially pressed. This event can be sent to Window, Document, and Element objects.
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerdown.title: GlobalEventHandlers.onpointerdown

dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerenter.name: onpointerenter
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerenter.summary: The onpointerenter property of the GlobalEventHandlers mixin is an EventHandler that processes pointerenter events.
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerenter.title: GlobalEventHandlers.onpointerenter

dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerleave.name: onpointerleave
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerleave.summary: The global event handler for the pointerleave event, which is delivered to a Node when the pointer (mouse cursor, fingertip, etc.) exits its hit test area (for example, if the cursor exits an Element or Window's content area). This event is part of the Pointer Events API.
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerleave.title: GlobalEventHandlers.onpointerleave

dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointermove.name: onpointermove
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointermove.summary: The onpointermove property of the GlobalEventHandlers mixin is an EventHandler that processes pointermove events.
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointermove.title: GlobalEventHandlers.onpointermove

dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerout.name: onpointerout
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerout.summary: The onpointerout property of the GlobalEventHandlers mixin is an EventHandler that processes pointerout events.
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerout.title: GlobalEventHandlers.onpointerout

dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerover.name: onpointerover
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerover.summary: The onpointerover property of the GlobalEventHandlers mixin is an EventHandler that processes pointerover events.
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerover.title: GlobalEventHandlers.onpointerover

dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerup.name: onpointerup
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerup.summary: The onpointerup property of the GlobalEventHandlers mixin is an EventHandler that processes pointerup events.
dom-globaleventhandlers-onpointerup.title: GlobalEventHandlers.onpointerup

extensions-to-the-navigator-interface.name: maxTouchPoints
extensions-to-the-navigator-interface.summary: The maxTouchPoints read-only property of the Navigator interface returns the maximum number of simultaneous touch contact points are supported by the current device.
extensions-to-the-navigator-interface.title: Navigator.maxTouchPoints

dom-pointerevent-height.name: height
dom-pointerevent-height.summary: The height read-only property of the PointerEvent interface represents the height of the pointer's contact geometry, along the y-axis (in CSS pixels). Depending on the source of the pointer device (for example a finger), for a given pointer, each event may produce a different value.

ie.notes: Returns values in screen pixels instead of CSS document pixels.

dom-pointerevent-height.title: PointerEvent.height

dom-pointerevent-isprimary.name: isPrimary
dom-pointerevent-isprimary.summary: The isPrimary read-only property of the PointerEvent interface indicates whether or not the pointer device that created the event is the primary pointer. It returns true if the pointer that caused the event to be fired is the primary device and returns false otherwise.
dom-pointerevent-isprimary.title: PointerEvent.isPrimary

dom-pointerevent-pointerid.name: pointerId
dom-pointerevent-pointerid.summary: The pointerId read-only property of the PointerEvent interface is an identifier assigned to a given pointer event. The identifier is unique, being different from the identifiers of all other active pointer events. Since the value may be randomly generated, it is not guaranteed to convey any particular meaning.
dom-pointerevent-pointerid.title: PointerEvent.pointerId

dom-pointerevent-pointertype.name: pointerType
dom-pointerevent-pointertype.summary: The pointerType read-only property of the PointerEvent interface indicates the device type (mouse, pen, or touch) that caused a given pointer event.

ie.notes: Returns an integer enumeration instead of a string.

dom-pointerevent-pointertype.title: PointerEvent.pointerType

dom-pointerevent-pressure.name: pressure
dom-pointerevent-pressure.summary: The pressure read-only property of the PointerEvent interface indicates the normalized pressure of the pointer input.

ie.notes: Returns 0 instead of 0.5 on hardware that doesn't support pressure.

dom-pointerevent-pressure.title: PointerEvent.pressure

dom-pointerevent-tangentialpressure.name: tangentialPressure
dom-pointerevent-tangentialpressure.summary: The tangentialPressure read-only property of the PointerEvent interface represents the normalized tangential pressure of the pointer input (also known as barrel pressure or cylinder stress).
dom-pointerevent-tangentialpressure.title: PointerEvent.tangentialPressure

dom-pointerevent-tiltx.name: tiltX
dom-pointerevent-tiltx.summary: The tiltX read-only property of the PointerEvent interface is the angle (in degrees) between the Y-Z plane of the pointer and the screen. This property is typically only useful for a pen/stylus pointer type.
dom-pointerevent-tiltx.title: PointerEvent.tiltX

dom-pointerevent-tilty.name: tiltY
dom-pointerevent-tilty.summary: The tiltY read-only property of the PointerEvent interface is the angle (in degrees) between the X-Z plane of the pointer and the screen. This property is typically only useful for a pen/stylus pointer type.
dom-pointerevent-tilty.title: PointerEvent.tiltY

dom-pointerevent-twist.name: twist
dom-pointerevent-twist.summary: The twist read-only property of the PointerEvent interface represents the clockwise rotation of the pointer (e.g., pen stylus) around its major axis, in degrees.
dom-pointerevent-twist.title: PointerEvent.twist

dom-pointerevent-width.name: width
dom-pointerevent-width.summary: The width read-only property of the PointerEvent interface represents the width of the pointer's contact geometry along the x-axis, measured in CSS pixels. Depending on the source of the pointer device (such as a finger), for a given pointer, each event may produce a different value.

ie.notes: Returns values in screen pixels instead of CSS document pixels.

dom-pointerevent-width.title: PointerEvent.width

pointerevent-interface.name: PointerEvent
pointerevent-interface.summary: The PointerEvent interface represents the state of a DOM event produced by a pointer such as the geometry of the contact point, the device type that generated the event, the amount of pressure that was applied on the contact surface, etc.
pointerevent-interface.title: PointerEvent

the-touch-action-css-property.name: touch-action
the-touch-action-css-property.summary: The touch-action CSS property sets how an element's region can be manipulated by a touchscreen user (for example, by zooming features built into the browser).

firefox.notes: Not applicable to Firefox platforms that support neither pointer nor touch events.
Not applicable to Firefox platforms that support neither pointer nor touch events.

the-touch-action-css-property.title: touch-action
